results.location_name: Cali, Valle del Cauca, Colombia

results.notes:
Association of several different lichens on the same substrata always fascinate me. It is a big challenge to identify to species its elements. In the present case I chose a group of three lichen, growing on the bark of the same tree, belonging to three of the biggest lichen genera: Buellia, Lecanora and Pertusaria. This step is quite easy for people used to observe and study lichens, maybe with the exception of the first one, due to the existence of other similar looking genera.
I created an observation for each species in the group.

This observation refers to the lichen with black apothecia occupying the central part of the photo with them all.
Going to the microscopy even Buellia can be already understood from an apothecial section. Some of its features are:
- Hymenium perfectly clear; Epithecium thin, brown; hypothecium dark brown;
- Thaline exciple well developed formed by thick hyphae giving a tressed appearance (similar to what can be observed in Lecidella, for instance)
- The algar layer can hardly be notice from a section;
- The asci are clavate, 8-spored, mostly with a bisseriate arrangement of spores;
- The spores are 1-septate, hyaline at first with some thick walls and septum, soon brown; Some have the apices lighter; Dimensions: to be updated (in the ranges 17-20 × 6-9 µm).
results.location_name: Carnaxide, Oeiras, Portugal

results.notes:
Association of several different lichens on the same substrata always fascinate me. It is a big challenge to identify to species its elements. In the present case I chose a group of three lichen, growing on the bark of the same tree, belonging to three of the biggest lichen genera: Buellia, Lecanora and Pertusaria. This step is quite easy for people used to observe and study lichens, maybe with the exception of the first one, due to the existence of other similar looking genera.
I created an observation for each species in this group.

This observation refers to the lichen with lecanorin apothecia in the group photo (at the bottom) that clearly belongs to the genus Lecanora. It is a quite common here or at least there are many with this overall appearance. Under the microscope from an apothecial section one can see the existence of big crystals in the exciplular zone. These crystals are insoluble in KOH as shown in the attached photos, using polarized light. Some crystal powder also exist in the epihymenium, but is hard to see and are barely invisible under polarized light, being soluble in KOH (as far as I could understand). The asci are clavate, 8-spored. The spores are simple (some are 1-septate, as is usual in this genus), hyaline with the following dimensions:
(10.4) 10.8 – 13.9 (14.5) × (5.9) 6.1 – 7 (8.1) µm
Q = (1.3) 1.6 – 2.1 (2.2) ; N = 22
Me = 12.2 × 6.7 µm ; Qe = 1.8 .
results.location_name: Carnaxide, Oeiras, Portugal

results.notes:
Association of several different lichens on the same substrata always fascinate me. It is a big challenge to identify to species its elements. In the present case I chose a group of three lichen, growing on the bark of the same tree, belonging to three of the biggest lichen genera: Buellia, Lecanora and Pertusaria. This step is quite easy for people used to observe and study lichens, maybe with the exception of the first one, due to the existence of other similar looking genera.
I created an observation for each species in this group.

This observation refers to the to the lichen with verruca-like apothecia in the group photo (at the top and right part of it) that clearly belong to the genus Pertusaria. It is one of the genera very well represented at this place. In a neigbhouring tree a specimen parasited by a Sphinctrina sp. was observed and will be consider at another observation. Specimens with similar appearance and chemistry caused me several problems in the past until I knew about the species P. heterochroa, a mediterranean species, considered at the reference and compared there with similar species. In addition to the particular chemistry the spores are, in general, striated and with a big halo. Their average dimensions measured are: 100.1 × 39 um ; Qe = 2.6. The asci have mostly 2-spores, but there are some with only one (as the photo from the microscopy shows).

results.notes:
These small little balls, only noticed by the intense shine under the incidence of sun light, literally covered some of the shrubs (see the photos of the habitat) which make the “frontier” between common soil and the sand of the dunes close to the sea. Most of these shrubs are relatively poor in lichen, while others have some Ramalina spp. and Lecanora spp.. Those dressed with Thelopsis, which I think to be the genus of these specimens due the similarity with observation 164774, also had many specimens of Dirina ceratoniae, one of the species that I only found at this zone of the country. I can hardly wait for the opportunity to observe them under the scope.
Curiously I think that this same day I found another colony at the place of my previous observation, cited above.

Santa Ana, Uruguay
Villa Crespo, Buenos Aires, Argentina

results.notes:
These “tulip tree morels” were all found growing near white ash trees. This forest also includes plenty of tulip poplar, but I found none of these morels near the tulip poplar. Some years, all or most of these are found in the same forest near tulip poplar. I interpret this as an indication of how the fruiting of these small forest yellows likely depends upon the relative timing of the trees preparing to foliate, the soil temperature, and moisture level. This year the weather warmed and the tulip poplar started to leaf out, but there was no rainfall for about 10 days. The rain seems to have returned too late for the early-foliating poplar but in time for the late-foliating ash trees to stimulate the reproductive mechanism of this Morchella.

Not exactly what one would call a “big haul” of morels. But for my area this represents a decent fruiting of this type.

results.notes:
Found in a burn area the first year after a fire. The closest tree was a burned out pine with barely a charred stump left. Douglas Fir was also in the area. The fruiting body was very dense, heavy to lift the full thing, and cold, much colder then the surface of the soil. The outer edge of the fruiting body had a very light lavender color that was not captured well by the cell phone photographs.

Spores are smooth, elongated and tend to have 1-2 oil drops in them. Approximately 15-18 um in length

I cooked a few slices in a neutral oil and it had an egg white like flavor but with a lingering background of a nitrile glove, but not in an offensive manner. It was difficult to brown the mushroom even in high heat.

I took a few slices of the main fruiting body and dried them down for my personal herbarium.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_953/2016_DSC1784

Habitat: Young riparian forest, Picea abies and Salix eleagnos dominant trees, next to a river; flat terrain occasionally flooded during high water levels of the river, calcareous, young alluvial ground; in shade, humid ground and air; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 530 m (1.740 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: fallen trunk of an old Salix eleagnos mostly not in direct contact with ground, still in bark, moss covered, in the late disintegration phase.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča, between villages Soča and Trenta, next to the farm house Otokar, Trenta 4, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comments: According to its species name Polyporus ciliatus should have distinctly fringed edge of the pileus. However, this was barely so with this find. Apparently this trait is not very reliable. However, very small pores, barely seen by naked eye (6 pores/mm measured) and appearance in spring clearly distinct it from very similar Polyporus brumalis.

About 50 pilei found on two places. Growing solitary and in groups, occasionally two fruitbodies confluent at the base of the stipe; pilei diameter from 35 to 70 mm, pore layer thin, up to 3 mm; stipe 3 – 5 cm long, 4 – 6 mm in diameter, equal and somewhat thicker at the base; pilei surprisingly sturdy, quite hard to cut and chew; smell mild, pleasant, mushroomy; taste distinct, mushroomy, somewhat unpleasant; SP abundant, whitish-light beige, oac851.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5
results.location_name: Lower Trenta Valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes:

Habitat: Young riparian forest, Picea abies and Salix eleagnos dominant trees, next to a river; flat terrain occasionally flooded during high water levels of the river, calcareous, young alluvial ground; in shade, humid ground and air; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 530 m (1.740 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: fallen trunk of an old Salix eleagnos, still in bark, moss covered, in the late disintegration phase.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča, between villages Soča and Trenta, next to the farm house Otokar, Trenta 4, south part of the riparian forest, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comments: According to its species name Polyporus ciliatus should have distinctly fringed edge of the pileus. However, this was barely so with this find. Apparently this trait is not very reliable. However, very small pores, barely seen by naked eye (6 pores/mm measured) and appearance in spring clearly distinct it from very similar Polyporus brumalis.

Five pilei found on south part of this riparian forest. Growing mostly solitary; pilei diameter from 45 to 70 mm, pore layer thin, up to 3 mm; stipe 3 – 6 cm long, 4 – 7 mm in diameter, equal and somewhat thicker at the base; pilei surprisingly sturdy, quite hard to cut; SP abundant, whitish-light beige, oac851.

results.notes:
Clitocybe pruinosa (Lasch) P. Kumm., Tricholomataceae, Agaricales
(Говорушка снежная, син. – весенняя)

Small light brown up to pinkish vernal mushroom
Cap: 1.5-3.5cm wide, slightly convex with depressed centre (margin curved down when young), then up to almost flat edges with wide central depression (rarely up to funnel-shaped); indistinct concentric colouring, the colour light beige, light yellowish-brown or pinkish light brown with irregular white fine fur or powder above a skin. Flesh is thin and whitish, odour is weak and pleasant (mealy or common mushroom aroma).
Gills: descending stalk, narrow up to moderately wide, rather close and almost distant, with short and very short additional gills, whitish up to yellowish-white.
Stalk: 2.5-3.5 cm long, 0.3-0.5cm thick, some fibrous, partially hollow when old, pinkish or brownish-white with irregular white fine fur or powder above a skin.
Habitat: common kind; scattered small groups in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
Season: April – May.
Edibility: no accurate data for this location, some internet notes that edible.

results.notes:
These specimens grew some 30 meters away from the place of observation 75714, where at least one specimen still exist (maybe it will be considered in a different observation), growing on the rocks just above the sea. The place is on the border of two of my locations, so I preserve the original location given.
At the time of that observation when identified this species as Buella maritima (see the notes and references therein) I became aware of the existence of a similar species, B. stellulata, that some authors treat as a synonym, differing mainly in the chemistry: the latter has no lichen substances while the former has norstictic acid, causing a K+ yellow to red reaction, producing red crystals. This time the chemistry on thallus, made with the help of spot test, was negative: C-, K-, KC-. Moreover, the medulla observed under the scope is I-. However, when analyzing the hymenium under the scope, some minutes after adding a drop of KOH to the slide, I noticed the formation of orange/red crystals (as shown in the photos). I see no other interpretation than the existence of norstictic acid (maybe in a low concentration). This reaction made me believe that my identification was correct and, thus I keep the name given some years ago.
I took the opportunity to get plenty of photos of the spores that are somewhat uncommon in my observations of species in this genus: many are broadly ellipsoide to subglobose, in addition to being small.

results.notes:
Entoloma vernum S. Lundell, Entolomataceae, Agaricales
(Early Spring Entoloma = Энтолома весенняя)

Small mushroom with brown knobbed cap and fibrous stalk
Cap: 2.5-5 cm wide, convex or cone with a knob or blunt cone then gentle convex or wide cone with a knob up to flatten minor sunken with knob (when old); dark brownish-gray or chocolate minor reddish-brown (when young) up to dull brown or light yellowish-brown when old; surface smooth or glossy (when wet); often radial lined out of knob (minor indistinct lined). Flesh is whitish when young, then brownish. Odour is weak mealy or common mushroom aroma.
Gills: almost free or attached with notched edge (pinching out end), light brown up to light reddish-brown when old, close and narrow up to moderately broad with short and very short additional gills (sometime broad gills when old).
Stalk: 3.5-6 cm long, 0.4-0.8cm thick, fibrous and hollow, grayish-brown or dull brown up to purplish-brown or light reddish-brown (when old and dry).
Edibility: poisonous or not edible
Habitat: scattered small groups up to abundant in pine-tree forest with some birches
Season: April – May

results.notes:
On old ranch fence boards, common. In a rural foothill woodland landscape with oaks and pine and grassland pastures.

Thallus whitish grey, often in an almond shape, without prothallus, C-, K+Y, UV-. Medulla white. Apothecia black, plane with margin when young becoming convex, not pruinose, crowded in thallus center. Hymenium not inspersed with oil droplets. Paraphyses with brown caps. Pycnidia not seen.

Spores 8 per ascus, 3 septate, narrowly ellipsoid, often curved. Measurements: 19.7×5.7
20.4×5.5
17.7×5.8
18.9×6.1

The chemistry of Buellia triseptata is indicated in Nash Sonoran Flora as K- and this description is what is listed in CNALH. I haven’t looked up the original species description. But, the 2010 Giralt paper listed above indicates the new chemotype as well as the original chemotype are K+, with the main difference being Chemotype 1 is K+Yellow with atronorin and Chemotype 2 (presumably the newly described one) being K+Orange with xanthones in addition to the atranorin.

This observation is a 2016 collection that represents what I believe is photographed in observation 197723. It occurs with Thelomma occidentalis, Cyphelium tigillare, Candelaria pacifica and others.

results.notes:
I only saw this species once (observation 113089) and it was in the way to the target point of that field trip, more than three and a half years ago. However, the information that I got at the time about it (mainly from Jason Hollinger, of course) permited me to recognize these specimens immediately. If at the first time the thallus was small, this time I could see two sets of thalli (the other will be considered at another observation) both with specimens at different stages of development. Moreover, in the other set there were fertile specimens, which permits to rule out the only similar species existing here: P. extenuata.
The habitat was shared with other lichens: mainly several species of Cladonia, some species of Leptogium, Polychidium muscicola

results.notes:
A scattered group of at least a dozen fruiting bodies growing singly and in small clusters of 2-4 sporocarps in sandy soil under pitch pines. These are probably the first mycorrhizal fungi to appear in the Pine Barrens. The leccinum, T. felleus and I. badia are to follow in 2-3 weeks.
An attempt to remove the mushrooms by gently pulling them by the stipe from the compacted ground failed (I didn’t have any equipment with me as it was just a hike) — the stipe snapped off right above the surface, leaving the presumed bulb in the ground.
> The largest fb had a cap diameter of 6.7 cm.
> There was quite a bit of gill forking and reverse forking, particularly in the youngest fb. Lamellulae are plentiful and of different lengths.
> The odor was funky, but not unpleasant, and somewhat familiar.
> The spore print is brown.
> A quick look in the scope at x400 revealed chicken egg-shaped, smooth spores. Spore measurements and pix will be posted later.

results.notes: A single fb that has seen better days. It probably popped up before the big rain we had two days ago. Likely one of the first mycorrhizal fungi to appear in the spring in the Pine Barrens. It was growing in sand under a wooden guardrail and was somewhat protected from the exposure to the elements. The gill edges appeared darker than the gill surface. There was a funky and unpleasant (mealy, spermatic?) odor. The spore print I got was very faint, but it was clearly brown. A quick look in the scope at 400 revealed smooth, almond-shaped spores with an olive-green cast (no solvent or cover slip). Spore measurements and pix will be posted later

Tiny yellowish-brown mushroom with elastic narrow long brownish stalk
Cap: 0.5-2 cm wide convex when young then wide convex with tiny gentle knob up to almost flat with slightly sunken centre and thin margin; smooth, sometimes radial lined; colour light yellowish-brown minor brown
Flesh is very thin and whitish or brownish-white; odour is weak and pleasant.
Gills: almost free or attached with pinching out, moderately broad minor narrow, rather close and almost distant with short and very short additional gills, whitish, somewhat light yellowish- or brownish-white.
Stalk: 3.5-6 cm long, 1.2-2.0mm thick, light yellowish-brown, some elastic and fibrous (fine velvety or hairy outer tube). Stalk base often looks as a tree root or long inner tube, sometimes twice longer than outer tube.
Edibility: no accurate data for this location; edible in other sites.
Habitat: scattered single or small groups on soil in pine-tree forest with some birches.
April – May

results.notes:
Finally I could understand in a great part the thalli of lichens that I can see in this mountains, mainly in its part consisting of granitic outcrops. From the beginning of my lichen observations here and up to very recently I thought that most of the lichen with overall appearance similar to those of this observation, say more or less rounded and surrounded by a black prothallus, part in general more or less fimbriate, belong to the genus Rhizocarpon. Those with yellowish areolas making part of the so-called Rhizocarpon geographicum group (in sensu lato).
Sometime ago I started to see that this is not so, and that many of those formely thought to be Rhizocarpon do not belong to that genus: Miriquidica is one of them (see e.g. observation 203979). More recently, I was also able to isolate from that group another characteristic form: Rinodina aspersa (see e.g. observation 236229 and the references therein to former observations). On the other hand, some of the specimens with that overall similar appearance have characteristic apothecia which do not fit in the genus Rhizocarpon and some were already recognized to be Rinodina atrocinerea (see e.g. observation 236227).
It should be noted that this taxon was previously named as Rinodina aspersa var. atrocinerea and was separated from the main variety for being usually fertile, the chemistry being the same though: C+ red, K+ yellow and KC+red. In the field, if the apothecia are not yet fully developed, then the two can be confused; this was the main reason for the troubles I had in identifying the specimen in observation 237387 (from a different location). To make the things worst, as you can see in some of the photos of this observation, the mature apothecia loose their thalline rim with age and the old apothecia become more or less coallescent, giving the appearance of brownish soredia when observed with the naked eye, but clearly seen with a macro photo.
I uploaded several photos of R. atrocinnerea. This species is well represented here and it lives together with: Rinodina aspersa, white and yellow Rhizocarpon, Miriquidica deusta, several Aspicilia spp., Diploschistes spp., _Lecanora spp., just to mention some of the other crustose lichens usually present.
Of course, since the specimens are fertile these thoughts must be confirmed with the microscopy, which I intend to do soon.
